Extended Formulations for Order Polytopes
through Network Flows

Clintin P. Davis-Stober cstober2@gmail.com University of Missouri, Columbia. Jean-Paul Doignon111Corresponding author: Jean-Paul Doignon doignon@ulb.ac.be Université Libre de Bruxelles, Belgium Samuel Fiorini sfiorini@ulb.ac.be Université Libre de Bruxelles, Belgium. François Glineur glineur@core.ucl.ac.be Université Catholique de Louvain, Belgium. Michel Regenwetter regenwet@uiuc.edu University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.
Abstract

Mathematical psychology has a long tradition of modeling probabilistic choice via distribution-free random utility models and associated random preference models. For such models, the predicted choice probabilities often form a bounded and convex polyhedral set, or polytope. Polyhedral combinatorics have thus played a key role in studying the mathematical structure of these models. However, standard methods for characterizing the polytopes of such models are subject to a combinatorial explosion in complexity as the number of choice alternatives increases. Specifically, this is the case for random preference models based on linear, weak, semi- and interval orders. For these, a complete, linear description of the polytope is currently known only for, at most, 5–8 choice alternatives. We leverage the method of extended formulations to break through those boundaries. For each of the four types of preferences, we build an appropriate network, and show that the associated network flow polytope provides an extended formulation of the polytope of the choice model. This extended formulation has a simple linear description that is more parsimonious than descriptions obtained by standard methods for large numbers of choice alternatives. The result is a computationally less demanding way of testing the probabilistic choice model on data. We sketch how the latter interfaces with recent developments in contemporary statistics.

keywords:
Order Polytopes , Extended Formulations , Network Flows , Probabilistic Choice , Distribution Free Random Utility

[2010] 06A07 , 52B12 , 91E99

1 Introduction

Much of the literature on choice behavior in the social sciences centers on modeling the unobservable hypothetical preferences or cognitive processes underlying observable choice behavior. This endeavor encounters a huge hurdle in empirical applications: How can models accommodate heterogeneity in choice behavior across individuals as well as within any given individual? To this end, researchers have employed a variety of probabilistic modeling approaches. Prominent examples include computational, stochastic process models that mimic hypothetical cognitive processes, such as the well-known diffusion model (e.g., Ratcliff & Smith, 2004, Ratcliff & Rouder, 1998) and the linear ballistic accumulator model (Brown & Heathcote, 2008, Trueblood et al., 2014). Other approaches include multinomial processing tree models (see, e.g., Erdfelder et al., 2009, for a review). Rather than model latent cognitive processes, we concentrate on the more abstract notion of latent preferences. In so doing, we consider models that use a minimum of mathematical assumptions and that delineate large classes of theories of choice behavior. This approach is grounded in a long tradition of axiomatization and axiom testing in mathematical psychology (see, e.g., Luce, 2000) and naturally interfaces with contemporary statistical methods (Davis-Stober & Brown, 2011, Davis-Stober et al., 2015). Evaluating choice data against such models allows for strong inferences regarding the latent preferences that give rise to choice behavior. Here, we tackle challenges with the mathematical characterization of such models.

Specifically, we consider classes of choice theories based upon four types of transitive binary preference relations: linear orders (rankings without ties), weak orders (rankings with or without ties), semiorders (partial rankings up to a constant threshold of discrimination), and interval orders (partial rankings up to a stimulus-dependent threshold of discrimination). For each of these algebraic representations of preferences, we consider probabilistic choice induced by an (unspecified) probability distribution over permissible preference states, i.e., over relations of the selected type. These models are also known in the literature as random preference models, mixture models, or random relation models. Because each of these models has been shown to have a random utility representation, our results also directly apply to characterizing various kinds of distribution-free random utility models, as well as random function models (see, e.g., Regenwetter & Marley, 2001).

Among the most important applications of these models are studies aimed at testing whether decision makers have transitive preferences (e.g., because they employ compensatory decision strategies by which they coherently trade-off between competing decision attributes) or whether they violate transitivity (say, because they employ simple heuristics that cause ‘incoherent’ preferences). It is well-known (Roberts, 1979) that, for finitely many choice options, complete asymmetric binary preferences are transitive if and only if they are strict linear orders. Dropping the requirement of complete preference, asymmetric binary preferences on a finite set of choice options are negatively transitive (hence also transitive) if and only if they are strict weak orders (Roberts, 1979). Testing random preference models on laboratory data faces two main hurdles: i) Because the model ranges of these models form convex polytopes (that is, bounded convex polyhedral sets as in Ziegler 1998), they require order-constrained statistical methods; ii) The order constraints (geometrically, the linear inequalities defining facets of the polytope) are fully known only when the number of choice alternatives is small. Recent developments have essentially solved the first challenge (see Davis-Stober, 2009, Karabatsos, 2006, Klugkist & Hoijtink, 2007, Myung et al., 2005, Silvapulle & Sen, 2005).

Using some of these approaches, Regenwetter et al. (2011a) provided the first empirical and statistically adequate test of the “linear ordering model” in the literature. Following Tversky (1969), they used five choice alternatives per stimulus set. Regenwetter & Davis-Stober (2012), who reported the first empirical test of the “weak order model,” also used five choice alternatives per stimulus set, in this case because the mathematical structure of the weak order polytope is not yet fully understood for larger numbers of choice alternatives. Regenwetter & Davis-Stober (2011) used four choice alternatives to test the “semiorder model” and the “interval order model” because they did not know a full description of the corresponding polytopes for more than four options.

In this article, we leverage extended formulations. We study network flow polytopes to characterize random preference models of linear, weak, semi-, and interval orders in novel ways. This approach generates a simpler, more parsimonious description of the corresponding random preference model and allows empirical researchers to study these models for larger numbers of choice alternatives than previously possible.

The paper proceeds as follows. First, we review key facts about linear, weak, semi-, and interval orders. Then, we discuss the convex polytopes associated with the random preference models based on each of these four types of preference relations and the obstacles faced by traditional mathematical methods for characterizing their model ranges. The following two sections overcome these obstacles and investigate extended formulations, especially those based on network flows, and associated network flow polytopes. We then discuss how these network flow polytopes interface with some contemporary developments in statistics. We end with a summary and detail future directions of this work.

2 Models of Pairwise Preferences and their Numerical Representations

Throughout the paper, S𝑆S denotes a finite set of n𝑛n choice alternatives (thus, |S|=n𝑆𝑛|S|=n). The preferences of a decision maker among the alternatives are cast as a relation R𝑅R on S𝑆S, with i​R​j𝑖𝑅𝑗i\,R\,j meaning that the decision maker likes i𝑖i strictly less than j𝑗j (hence strictly prefers j𝑗j over i𝑖i). In a simple case, the relation R𝑅R is a linear order, that is an irreflexive, transitive and complete relation (for a definition of these and similar terms, see for instance Fishburn 1985, Chapter 1, or Pirlot & Vincke 1997, Chapter 3). As is well-known, such an ideal situation occurs when preferences reflect comparisons of utility values and no two choice alternatives have the same utility.

Proposition 1 (Linear order).

The relation R𝑅R on the set S𝑆S of alternatives is a linear order if and only if there exists an injective mapping u:S→ℝ:𝑢→𝑆ℝu:\;S\to\mathbb{R} such that, for all i𝑖i, j𝑗j in S𝑆S:

i​R​j⇔u​(i)<u​(j).iff𝑖𝑅𝑗𝑢𝑖𝑢𝑗i\,R\,j\;\iff\;u(i)<u(j). (1)

If we drop the injectivity condition in Proposition 1, thus making room for alternatives having equal utility, we get a (strict) weak order (an asymmetric and negatively transitive relation).

Proposition 2 (Weak order).

The relation R𝑅R on the set S𝑆S of alternatives is a weak order if and only if there exists a mapping u:S→ℝ:𝑢→𝑆ℝu:\;S\to\mathbb{R} such that, for all i𝑖i, j𝑗j in S𝑆S:

i​R​j⇔u​(i)<u​(j).iff𝑖𝑅𝑗𝑢𝑖𝑢𝑗i\,R\,j\;\iff\;u(i)<u(j). (2)

In many situations, comparing utility values defined as real numbers is not realistic. According to an extended viewpoint, any alternative i𝑖i from S𝑆S is assigned a range of values taking the form of a real interval [ℓ​(i),h​(i)]ℓ𝑖ℎ𝑖[\ell(i),h(i)] in such a way that i​R​j𝑖𝑅𝑗i\,R\,j holds exactly if the interval [ℓ​(i),h​(i)]ℓ𝑖ℎ𝑖[\ell(i),h(i)] lies entirely before the interval [ℓ​(j),h​(j)]ℓ𝑗ℎ𝑗[\ell(j),h(j)] (see Figure 1 for a geometric illustration). The relation R𝑅R is then called an interval order on S𝑆S. Here, one may interpret ℓ​(i)ℓ𝑖\ell(i) as the lower utility value of i𝑖i, h​(i)ℎ𝑖h(i) as the upper utility value, and h​(i)−ℓ​(i)ℎ𝑖ℓ𝑖h(i)-\ell(i) as a perceptual threshold for utilities. We call such a pair of mappings (ℓ,h)ℓℎ(\ell,h) a representation of R𝑅R.

A combinatorial characterization of interval orders, due independently to Fishburn (1970) and Mirkin (1972) (but also included in the result on ‘bi-quasi-series’ in Ducamp & Falmagne 1969), is as follows.

Proposition 3 (Interval order).

The relation R𝑅R on the set S𝑆S of alternatives satisfies the following two conditions, for all i𝑖i, j𝑗j, i′superscript𝑖′i^{\prime}, j′superscript𝑗′j^{\prime} in S𝑆S:

not ​(i​R​i);not 𝑖𝑅𝑖\displaystyle\text{not~{}}(i\,R\,i); (3)
(i​R​j​ and ​i′​R​j′)⟹(i​R​j′​ or ​i′​R​j)𝑖𝑅𝑗 and superscript𝑖′𝑅superscript𝑗′𝑖𝑅superscript𝑗′ or superscript𝑖′𝑅𝑗\displaystyle(i\,R\,j\text{ and }i^{\prime}\,R\,j^{\prime})\;\implies\;(i\,R\,j^{\prime}\text{ or }i^{\prime}\,R\,j) (4)

if and only if there exist two mappings ℓ,h:S→ℝ:ℓℎ→𝑆ℝ\ell,\,h:\;S\to\mathbb{R} such that the following two conditions hold, for all i𝑖i, j𝑗j in S𝑆S:

ℓ​(i)≤h​(i);ℓ𝑖ℎ𝑖\displaystyle\ell(i)\leq h(i); (5)
i​R​j⇔h​(i)<ℓ​(j).iff𝑖𝑅𝑗ℎ𝑖ℓ𝑗\displaystyle i\,R\,j\;\iff\;h(i)<\ell(j). (6)

When the threshold h​(i)−ℓ​(i)ℎ𝑖ℓ𝑖h(i)-\ell(i) in Proposition 3 is required to be independent of the alternative i𝑖i, we get the semiorder model, and say that the relation R𝑅R is a semiorder on S𝑆S. The latter model appears in Wiener (1915), Armstrong (1939) and Luce (1956) and was given its name by the last author. The following characterization is due to Scott & Suppes (1958).

Proposition 4 (Semiorder).

The relation R𝑅R on the set S𝑆S of alternatives satisfies the following three conditions, for all i𝑖i, j𝑗j, i′superscript𝑖′i^{\prime}, j′superscript𝑗′j^{\prime}, i′′superscript𝑖′′i^{\prime\prime} in S𝑆S:

not ​(i​R​i);not 𝑖𝑅𝑖\displaystyle\text{not~{}}(i\,R\,i);
(i​R​j​ and ​i′​R​j′)⟹(i​R​j′​ or ​i′​R​j);𝑖𝑅𝑗 and superscript𝑖′𝑅superscript𝑗′𝑖𝑅superscript𝑗′ or superscript𝑖′𝑅𝑗\displaystyle(i\,R\,j\text{ and }i^{\prime}\,R\,j^{\prime})\;\implies\;(i\,R\,j^{\prime}\text{ or }i^{\prime}\,R\,j);
(i​R​i′​ and ​i′​R​i′′)⟹(i​R​j​ or ​j​R​i′′)𝑖𝑅superscript𝑖′ and superscript𝑖′𝑅superscript𝑖′′𝑖𝑅𝑗 or 𝑗𝑅superscript𝑖′′\displaystyle(i\,R\,i^{\prime}\text{ and }i^{\prime}\,R\,i^{\prime\prime})\;\implies\;(i\,R\,j\text{ or }j\,R\,i^{\prime\prime})

if and only if there exist two mappings ℓ,h:S→ℝ:ℓℎ→𝑆ℝ\ell,h:\;S\to\mathbb{R} and a nonnegative real number r𝑟r such that the following two conditions hold, for all i𝑖i, j𝑗j in S𝑆S:

i​R​j⇔h​(i)<ℓ​(j);iff𝑖𝑅𝑗ℎ𝑖ℓ𝑗\displaystyle i\,R\,j\;\iff\;h(i)<\ell(j); (7)
h​(i)−ℓ​(i)=r.ℎ𝑖ℓ𝑖𝑟\displaystyle h(i)-\ell(i)=r. (8)

3 Random Preference Models and their Associated Polytopes

Relations like those of Propositions 1–4 can be used to model the decision maker’s preferences at a particular moment. In general, the decision maker may be uncertain about her preferences and may probabilistically sample a preference from some collection of preference states, when required to make decisions. We assume all permissible preference states obey the model selected. Thus, at any time we may interview the decision maker about any pair (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) of alternatives, and collect an answer reflecting her currently sampled preference. As a consequence, repeated interviews will lead to frequencies of having i​R​j𝑖𝑅𝑗i\,R\,j (or not). On the theoretical side, this leads us to posit a probability distribution P𝑃P on the set ℒ​𝒪Sℒsubscript𝒪𝑆\mathcal{LO}_{S} of all linear orders on S𝑆S—to take this model as an example; similar considerations of course hold in the other three models, for the collection 𝒲​𝒪S𝒲subscript𝒪𝑆\mathcal{WO}_{S} of all weak orders, ℐ​𝒪Sℐsubscript𝒪𝑆\mathcal{IO}_{S} of all interval orders, or 𝒮​𝒪S𝒮subscript𝒪𝑆\mathcal{SO}_{S} of all semiorders. With P​(R)𝑃𝑅P(R) denoting the probability that the decision maker’s (currently sampled) relation is R𝑅R, we assume that the probability that she prefers alternative j𝑗j over alternative i𝑖i is given by the following formula:

p(i,j)=∑{P​(R)​ ​R∈ℒ​𝒪S​ with ​i​R​j}.subscript𝑝𝑖𝑗𝑃𝑅 𝑅ℒsubscript𝒪𝑆 with 𝑖𝑅𝑗p_{(i,j)}\;=\;\sum\;\{P(R){\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}R\in\mathcal{LO}_{S}\text{ with }i\,R\,j\}. (9)

Not all collections of real values {p(i,j)​ ​(i,j)∈S×S}subscript𝑝𝑖𝑗 𝑖𝑗𝑆𝑆\{p_{(i,j)}{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}(i,j)\in S\times S\} can be produced in this way, for a probability distribution P𝑃P on ℒ​𝒪Sℒsubscript𝒪𝑆\mathcal{LO}_{S}. For instance, Equation (9) implies p(i,j)≥0subscript𝑝𝑖𝑗0p_{(i,j)}\geq 0 and, for any i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j, p(i,j)+p(j,i)=1subscript𝑝𝑖𝑗subscript𝑝𝑗𝑖1p_{(i,j)}+p_{(j,i)}=1. Other necessary conditions are known, but necessary and sufficient conditions are known only for small values of n𝑛n. There are doubts that a tractable set of necessary and sufficient conditions could be found that is valid for all n𝑛n (because the ‘linear ordering problem’ is NP-hard, see Garey & Johnson, 1979). To get a better understanding of the collections {p(i,j)​ ​(i,j)∈S×S}subscript𝑝𝑖𝑗 𝑖𝑗𝑆𝑆\{p_{(i,j)}{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}(i,j)\in S\times S\} that satisfy Equation (9) for at least one probability distribution P𝑃P on ℒ​𝒪Sℒsubscript𝒪𝑆\mathcal{LO}_{S}, we now develop a geometric interpretation and we do the same later for the other three models.

Each linear order on the set S𝑆S, being a collection of pairs of alternatives of S𝑆S, is a subset of S×S𝑆𝑆S\times S. Because linear orders (as well as the other orders we consider in this paper) are irreflexive, they never contain a pair of the form (i,i)𝑖𝑖(i,i), with i∈S𝑖𝑆i\in S. This prompts us to discard all pairs (i,i)𝑖𝑖(i,i), for i∈S𝑖𝑆i\in S. Let S⋆S:=(S×S)∖{(i,i)​ ​i∈S}assign⋆𝑆𝑆𝑆𝑆𝑖𝑖 𝑖𝑆S\star S:=(S\times S)\setminus\{(i,i){\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}i\in S\}. Consider the space ℝS⋆Ssuperscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆\mathbb{R}^{S\star S}, in which a point x𝑥x has a coordinate x(i,j)subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗x_{(i,j)} for each pair (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) of distinct alternatives from S𝑆S. To any linear order R𝑅R on S𝑆S, associate the point xRsuperscript𝑥𝑅x^{R} with coordinates given by

(xR)(i,j):={1if ​i​R​j,0otherwise.assignsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑅𝑖𝑗cases1if 𝑖𝑅𝑗0otherwise\left(x^{R}\right)_{(i,j)}\;:=\;\begin{cases}1&\text{if }i\,R\,j,\\ 0&\text{otherwise}.\end{cases} (10)

In other words, xRsuperscript𝑥𝑅x^{R} is the characteristic vector of the linear order R𝑅R. The convex hull in ℝS⋆Ssuperscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆\mathbb{R}^{S\star S} of the characteristic vectors of all linear orders on S𝑆S, that is the set of all convex combinations of those vectors (linear combinations with nonnegative coefficients summing to one), is the linear order polytope of S𝑆S, which we denote PLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑆P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}:

PLOS:=conv{xR​ ​R∈ℒ​𝒪S}.assignsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑆convsuperscript𝑥𝑅 𝑅ℒsubscript𝒪𝑆P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}\;:=\;\mathop{\mathrm{conv}}\;\{x^{R}{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}R\in\mathcal{LO}_{S}\}. (11)

A collection {p(i,j)​ ​(i,j)∈S⋆S}subscript𝑝𝑖𝑗 𝑖𝑗⋆𝑆𝑆\{p_{(i,j)}{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}(i,j)\in S\star S\} satisfies Equation (9) for at least one probability distribution P𝑃P on ℒ​𝒪Sℒsubscript𝒪𝑆\mathcal{LO}_{S} if and only if the point p𝑝p lies in the linear order polytope PLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑆P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}. Thus, to characterize such collections, we would like a criterion for a point x𝑥x from ℝS⋆Ssuperscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆\mathbb{R}^{S\star S} to lie in PLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑆P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}. A classical result (see, for instance, Ziegler 1998) states that any polytope admits a linear description, that is a finite system of linear equations and inequalities whose solution set is exactly the polytope. Even if we insist that the system has a minimum number of equations and inequalities, it is generally not unique; however, the number of linear equations is then the codimension of the polytope, and there is exactly one inequality per facet of the polytope. In the case of the linear order polytope PLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑆P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}, the number of equations on ℝS⋆Ssuperscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆\mathbb{R}^{S\star S} equals (n2)=n​(n−1)/2binomial𝑛2𝑛𝑛12\binom{n}{2}=n(n-1)/2 (those being the already mentioned p(i,j)+p(j,i)=1subscript𝑝𝑖𝑗subscript𝑝𝑗𝑖1p_{(i,j)}+p_{(j,i)}=1), but no precise estimation seems to be available on the number of inequalities. As far as we know, a complete linear description of PLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑆P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S} is lacking when |S|=n>7𝑆𝑛7|S|=n>7. For n=8𝑛8n=8, the number of vertices is 8!=40,3208403208!=40{,}320 but only a lower bound on the number of facets is available. This lower bound is huge: the polytope has at least 488,602,996488602996488{,}602{,}996 facets (Christof & Reinelt, 1996). For other results on the linear order polytope, we refer the reader to Doignon et al. (2006), Fiorini (2006a, b), Boyd & Pulleyblank (2009), Doignon et al. (2009), Oswald et al. (2009), Martí & Reinelt (2011) and their references. For an application of the linear order model to test transitivity of preferences on empirical data, see Regenwetter et al. (2010, 2011b, 2011a).

The weak order polytope of S𝑆S, which we denote by PWOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃WO𝑆P_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}, is similarly defined in ℝS⋆Ssuperscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆\mathbb{R}^{S\star S}:

PWOS:=conv{xR​ ​R∈𝒲​𝒪S}.assignsuperscriptsubscript𝑃WO𝑆convsuperscript𝑥𝑅 𝑅𝒲subscript𝒪𝑆P_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}\;:=\;\mathop{\mathrm{conv}}\;\{x^{R}{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}R\in\mathcal{WO}_{S}\}. (12)

Note in passing that several publications (e.g., Doignon & Fiorini, 2002, Fiorini & Fishburn, 2004) consider ‘complete weak orders.’ The latter are transitive and complete relations, in other words the inverses of the complements of weak orders. The resulting ‘complete weak order polytope’ is the image of our polytope PWOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃WO𝑆P_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S} by the affine transformation ℝS⋆S→ℝS⋆S:x↦x′:→superscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆superscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆maps-to𝑥superscript𝑥′\mathbb{R}^{S\star S}\to\mathbb{R}^{S\star S}:\;x\mapsto x^{\prime} with x(i,j)′=1−x(j,i)subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑥𝑗𝑖x^{\prime}_{(i,j)}=1-x_{(j,i)}. Hence, all the results about one of these polytopes have a counterpart for the other.

The Ph.D. dissertation of Fiorini (2001) contains an overview of results about the two order polytopes we just introduced, including a complete description of PW​OSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑊𝑂𝑆P_{WO}^{S} for |S|=n=4𝑆𝑛4|S|=n=4. To our knowledge, a complete description of PW​OSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑊𝑂𝑆P_{WO}^{S} is known only up to n=5𝑛5n=5. For n=5𝑛5n=5, the weak order polytope PW​OSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑊𝑂𝑆P_{WO}^{S} has 75,8347583475{,}834 facets and 541541541 vertices (Regenwetter & Davis-Stober, 2012).

Two other polytopes play a role in our study. They are the interval order polytope of S𝑆S

PIOS:=conv{xR​ ​R∈ℐ​𝒪S}assignsuperscriptsubscript𝑃IO𝑆convsuperscript𝑥𝑅 𝑅ℐsubscript𝒪𝑆P_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}\;:=\;\mathop{\mathrm{conv}}\;\{x^{R}{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}R\in\mathcal{IO}_{S}\} (13)

and the semiorder polytope of S𝑆S

PSOS:=conv{xR​ ​R∈𝒮​𝒪S}.assignsuperscriptsubscript𝑃SO𝑆convsuperscript𝑥𝑅 𝑅𝒮subscript𝒪𝑆P_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}\;:=\;\mathop{\mathrm{conv}}\;\{x^{R}{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}R\in\mathcal{SO}_{S}\}. (14)

The interval order polytope is investigated by Müller & Schulz (1995), the semiorder polytope by Suck (1995) and both of them by Doignon & Rexhep (2016). For n=4𝑛4n=4, Regenwetter & Davis-Stober (2011) reports that the interval order polytope has 207207207 vertices and 191191191 facets, while the figures for the semiorder polytope are 183183183 and 563563563.

4 Network Flow Representations of Order Polytopes

We now move to a third way of investigating our four order polytopes. Many applications in psychology and economics aim to evaluate random preference models on human subjects choice data from laboratory studies. This typically involves optimizing concave functions (e.g., a log-likelihood function) subject to the constraint that the choice probabilities belong to the polytope in question. Such optimizations are straightforward when the geometric structure of the polytope is fully known. The extended formulations that we now consider make it possible to solve some of these optimization goals in cases where obtaining a complete geometric representation of the polytope in question is computationally expensive.

4.1 The concept of an extended formulation

In the previous section, we described how testing whether a collection of choice probabilities satisfies the linear order model amounts to checking whether a given point lies in the linear order polytope PLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑆P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S} (we again base our exposition on this model), which can be done by checking the validity of each linear equation and inequality in its description). Unfortunately, unless we limit ourselves to small enough n𝑛n the latter task is made difficult or even impossible by the inherent intricacy, or sheer unavailability, of a linear description of PLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑆P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}. In this section, we sketch the main steps to overcome this difficulty. We provide technical constructions and proofs in the next section.

The main idea is to work with another, ad hoc polytope that projects in some specific way on PLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑆P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S} (more precisely: there is an affine transformation mapping the ad hoc polytope onto PLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑆P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}). Any linear description of such an ad hoc polytope is called an extended formulation of PLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑆P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}. For a survey of the notion of an extended formulation, see Conforti et al. (2010), Kaibel (2011) and Wolsey (2011). For the four order polytopes we study in this paper, the ad hoc polytope happens to be a “flow polytope”, so we first define the latter notion and review some known facts.

4.2 The concept of a network flow polytope

Let D=(N,A)𝐷𝑁𝐴D=(N,A) be a network with node set N𝑁N and arc set A𝐴A (for network terminology, see, for instance, Korte & Vygen, 2008). In N𝑁N, we designate two special nodes: the source node s𝑠s and the sink node t𝑡t.

For a node v𝑣v, we denote the sets of arcs leaving and entering v𝑣v by δ+​(v)superscript𝛿𝑣\delta^{+}(v) and δ−​(v)superscript𝛿𝑣\delta^{-}(v), respectively. Formally,

δ+​(v)superscript𝛿𝑣\displaystyle\delta^{+}(v) :=assign\displaystyle:= {a∈A​∃w∈N:a=(v,w)},conditional-set𝑎𝐴𝑤𝑁𝑎𝑣𝑤\displaystyle\{a\in A{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}\exists w\in N:a=(v,w)\},
δ−​(v)superscript𝛿𝑣\displaystyle\delta^{-}(v) :=assign\displaystyle:= {a∈A​∃t∈N:a=(t,v)}.conditional-set𝑎𝐴𝑡𝑁𝑎𝑡𝑣\displaystyle\{a\in A{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}\exists t\in N:a=(t,v)\}.

Consider a set B𝐵B of arcs in A𝐴A. We encode B𝐵B by its characteristic vector χBsuperscript𝜒𝐵\chi^{B} in ℝAsuperscriptℝ𝐴\mathbb{R}^{A}, defined by letting χaB:=1assignsubscriptsuperscript𝜒𝐵𝑎1\chi^{B}_{a}:=1 if a∈B𝑎𝐵a\in B and χaB:=0assignsubscriptsuperscript𝜒𝐵𝑎0\chi^{B}_{a}:=0 if a∈A∖B𝑎𝐴𝐵a\in A\setminus B (we notate the characteristic vectors xRsuperscript𝑥𝑅x^{R} and χBsuperscript𝜒𝐵\chi^{B} differently to emphasize that they refer to the distinct master sets S⋆S⋆𝑆𝑆S\star S and A𝐴A, respectively). For a vector ΦΦ\Phi in ℝAsuperscriptℝ𝐴\mathbb{R}^{A}, we define the number

Φ​(B):=∑a∈BΦa.assignΦ𝐵subscript𝑎𝐵subscriptΦ𝑎\Phi(B):=\sum_{a\in B}\Phi_{a}. (15)

A flow in D𝐷D is a vector ΦΦ\Phi from ℝAsuperscriptℝ𝐴\mathbb{R}^{A}, associating a nonnegative number ΦasubscriptΦ𝑎\Phi_{a} to each arc a𝑎a of the network, such that the out-flow Φ​(δ+​(v))Φsuperscript𝛿𝑣\Phi(\delta^{+}(v)) equals the in-flow Φ​(δ−​(v))Φsuperscript𝛿𝑣\Phi(\delta^{-}(v)) at each node v𝑣v distinct from the source node s𝑠s and the sink node t𝑡t. The value of a flow ΦΦ\Phi equals Φ​(δ+​(s))−Φ​(δ−​(s))Φsuperscript𝛿𝑠Φsuperscript𝛿𝑠\Phi(\delta^{+}(s))-\Phi(\delta^{-}(s)), that is, the net out-flow at the source node. A flow ΦΦ\Phi is said to be integral if ΦasubscriptΦ𝑎\Phi_{a} is an integer, for all arcs a𝑎a.

In the context of this work, we assume that the network D𝐷D is acyclic. We define the flow polytope F=F​(D)𝐹𝐹𝐷F=F(D) of the network D𝐷D as the polytope whose vertices are the characteristic vectors of the sets of arcs of all the s𝑠s–t𝑡t (directed) paths in D𝐷D. Any such characteristic vector is an integral s𝑠s–t𝑡t flow in D𝐷D of value 111. Because we assume that D𝐷D is acyclic, the converse also holds: any vector ΦΦ\Phi from ℝAsuperscriptℝ𝐴\mathbb{R}^{A} which is an integral s𝑠s–t𝑡t flow in D𝐷D of value 111 is the characteristic vector of an s𝑠s–t𝑡t path in D𝐷D. A complete linear description of F​(D)𝐹𝐷F(D) is as follows (see for instance Korte & Vygen, 2008, Theorem 8.8)—we call it the canonical description of the flow polytope F​(D)𝐹𝐷F(D):

F(D)={Φ∈ℝA Φ​(δ+​(v))−Φ​(δ−​(v))=0,∀v∈N∖{s,t},Φ​(δ+​(s))−Φ​(δ−​(s))=1,Φa⩾0,∀a∈A}.F(D)=\left\{\Phi\in\mathbb{R}^{A}\;\vrule height=23.0pt,width=1.0pt,depth=14.0pt\;\begin{array}[]{rcl@{\quad}l}\Phi(\delta^{+}(v))-\Phi(\delta^{-}(v))&=&0,&\forall v\in N\setminus\{s,t\},\\ \Phi(\delta^{+}(s))-\Phi(\delta^{-}(s))&=&1,\\ \Phi_{a}&\geqslant&0,&\forall a\in A\end{array}\right\}. (16)

Following the current practice in extended formulations, we define the size of a linear description as the total number of inequalities in the description, thus disregarding the number of variables and equalities, as well as the bit complexity of the coefficients. Hence, the size of the canonical description of F​(D)𝐹𝐷F(D) is |A|𝐴|A|.

Again, let S𝑆S denote the set of alternatives, with |S|=n𝑆𝑛|S|=n. We now show that three of our order polytopes, namely the linear order, weak order and interval order polytopes, share the following property for some constant c𝑐c associated with each family of polytopes: For each of these polytopes, there exists a flow polytope F𝐹F with a linear description of size O​(cn)𝑂superscript𝑐𝑛O(c^{n}) and a projection from ℝAsuperscriptℝ𝐴\mathbb{R}^{A} to ℝS⋆Ssuperscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆\mathbb{R}^{S\star S} that maps the flow polytope F𝐹F to the considered order polytope. We explicitly build this flow polytope, which is thus an extended formulation. We also build a flow polytope providing an extended formulation for the semiorder polytope with, surprisingly, canonical description size in Ω​(n!)Ω𝑛\Omega(n!), which is not O​(cn)𝑂superscript𝑐𝑛O(c^{n}) for any constant c𝑐c.

As we discuss later in Section 7, it follows from recent results that all our extended formulations are size-optimal, except perhaps that for the semiorder polytope. More precisely, any extended formulation for any of our order polytopes for a set of alternatives of size n𝑛n has size at least (3/2)⌊n/2⌋superscript32𝑛2(3/2)^{\lfloor n/2\rfloor}.

In order to specify the networks, the key idea is to use ordinal representations of the relations involved. We start with weak orders.

4.3 The case of weak orders

Remember from Proposition 2 that a relation R𝑅R on S𝑆S is a weak order exactly if there exists a mapping u𝑢u from S𝑆S to ℝℝ\mathbb{R} such that

i​R​j⇔u​(i)<u​(j).iff𝑖𝑅𝑗𝑢𝑖𝑢𝑗i\,R\,j\iff u(i)<u(j). (17)

For each τ𝜏\tau in ℝℝ\mathbb{R}, we let

X​(τ):={i∈S​ ​u​(i)<τ}.assign𝑋𝜏𝑖𝑆 𝑢𝑖𝜏X(\tau):=\{i\in S{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}u(i)<\tau\}. (18)

Now, imagine increasing the level τ𝜏\tau continuously from τ=min⁡u​(S)𝜏𝑢𝑆\tau=\min u(S) to τ=max⁡u​(S)+1𝜏𝑢𝑆1\tau=\max u(S)+1. Thus, we observe a finite sequence of distinct sets X0subscript𝑋0X_{0}, X1subscript𝑋1X_{1}, …, Xmsubscript𝑋𝑚X_{m}, starting with the empty set ∅\varnothing and ending with the entire set S𝑆S. We call this sequence the profile of the weak order R𝑅R (notice that the profile of the weak order R𝑅R does not depend on the representation of R𝑅R, and also that it determines R𝑅R). More formally, let u​(S)={τ0,τ1,…,τm−1}𝑢𝑆subscript𝜏0subscript𝜏1…subscript𝜏𝑚1u(S)=\{\tau_{0},\tau_{1},\dots,\tau_{m-1}\} with τ0<τ1<⋯<τm−1subscript𝜏0subscript𝜏1⋯subscript𝜏𝑚1\tau_{0}<\tau_{1}<\dots<\tau_{m-1}. For every k𝑘k in {0,1,…,m−1}01…𝑚1\{0,1,\ldots,m-1\}, set Xk:={i∈S​ ​u​(i)<τk}assignsubscript𝑋𝑘𝑖𝑆 𝑢𝑖subscript𝜏𝑘X_{k}:=\{i\in S{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}u(i)<\tau_{k}\}, and moreover Xm:=Sassignsubscript𝑋𝑚𝑆X_{m}:=S. The profile of the weak order R𝑅R forms a chain

∅=:X0⊂X1⊂⋯⊂Xm:=S.\varnothing=:X_{0}\subset X_{1}\subset\cdots\subset X_{m}:=S. (19)

(Here and throughout, ⊂\subset indicates strict inclusion.)

Now form the network whose nodes are the subsets of S𝑆S, letting s:=∅assign𝑠s:=\varnothing and t:=Sassign𝑡𝑆t:=S, and whose arcs are the pairs (X,Z)𝑋𝑍(X,Z) of subsets of S𝑆S such that X⊂Z𝑋𝑍X\subset Z. We see that the profile of each weak order R𝑅R determines an s𝑠s–t𝑡t path in this network. Conversely, any s𝑠s–t𝑡t path in this network determines a unique weak order. Because the two constructions correspond to mappings that are each other’s inverses, we get a bijection from the set of s𝑠s–t𝑡t paths to the set of weak orders on S𝑆S. Later (in Subsection 5.2), we prove that this bijection yields a projection from the flow polytope of the network we just built to the weak order polytope of S𝑆S.

4.4 The case of linear orders

We now turn to the linear orders on S𝑆S. In the above network (for weak orders), they correspond to the s𝑠s–t𝑡t paths that use only arcs (X,Z)𝑋𝑍(X,Z) where X⊂Z𝑋𝑍X\subset Z with the restriction that |X|+1=|Z|𝑋1𝑍|X|+1=|Z|. Because the s𝑠s–t𝑡t paths describing linear orders only use those arcs, we now delete all the other arcs from the network while keeping all the nodes. In the resulting network, the s𝑠s–t𝑡t paths bijectively correspond to the linear orders on S𝑆S. We later infer a projection from the flow polytope of this network to the linear order polytope of S𝑆S (see Theorem 1).

4.5 The case of interval orders

To create a network for interval orders, we use Proposition 3 according to which a relation R𝑅R on S𝑆S is an interval order when there exist two mappings ℓℓ\ell and hℎh from S𝑆S to ℝℝ\mathbb{R} such that ℓ​(i)⩽h​(i)ℓ𝑖ℎ𝑖\ell(i)\leqslant h(i) for all i∈S𝑖𝑆i\in S and

i​R​j⇔h​(i)<ℓ​(j).iff𝑖𝑅𝑗ℎ𝑖ℓ𝑗i\,R\,j\iff h(i)<\ell(j). (20)

In the following, we always assume that ℓℓ\ell and hℎh are both one-to-one, and that the images of S𝑆S under ℓℓ\ell and hℎh are disjoint. Why can we modify the mappings ℓℓ\ell and hℎh in order to satisfy these two conditions? Each value of ℓℓ\ell is only constrained by Equations (5) and (6) to lie in a convex subset of ℝℝ\mathbb{R} which is determined by the values of hℎh. Moreover this convex set has more than one point. Hence, we can always adjust values of ℓℓ\ell in order to make ℓℓ\ell one-to-one. Similarly, we can next adjust values of hℎh in order to make hℎh one-to-one and at the same time ℓ​(S)ℓ𝑆\ell(S) and h​(S)ℎ𝑆h(S) disjoint.

Each level τ𝜏\tau from ℝℝ\mathbb{R} determines two subsets of S𝑆S (for a geometric example, see Figure 2, but, for the moment, ignore the last sentence in the caption):

X​(τ)𝑋𝜏\displaystyle X(\tau) :=assign\displaystyle:= {i∈S​ℓ​(i)<τ},𝑖𝑆ℓ𝑖𝜏\displaystyle\{i\in S{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}\ell(i)<\tau\}, (21)
Y​(τ)𝑌𝜏\displaystyle Y(\tau) :=assign\displaystyle:= {i∈S​h​(i)<τ}.𝑖𝑆ℎ𝑖𝜏\displaystyle\{i\in S{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}h(i)<\tau\}. (22)

Because ℓ​(i)≤h​(i)ℓ𝑖ℎ𝑖\ell(i)\leq h(i) holds for all i∈S𝑖𝑆i\in S, we have Y​(τ)⊆X​(τ)𝑌𝜏𝑋𝜏Y(\tau)\subseteq X(\tau) for every level τ𝜏\tau. When we continuously increase τ𝜏\tau from τ=min⁡ℓ​(S)𝜏ℓ𝑆\tau=\min\ell(S) to τ=max⁡h​(S)+1𝜏ℎ𝑆1\tau=\max h(S)+1, we observe a finite sequence of distinct pairs of sets (X0,Y0)subscript𝑋0subscript𝑌0(X_{0},Y_{0}), (X1,Y1)subscript𝑋1subscript𝑌1(X_{1},Y_{1}), …, (Xm,Ym)subscript𝑋𝑚subscript𝑌𝑚(X_{m},Y_{m}) that forms the profile of the interval order R𝑅R (notice that the profile of an interval order R𝑅R technically depends on the chosen representation ℓℓ\ell, hℎh of R𝑅R; however, each such profile determines R𝑅R). Our assumptions on the mappings ℓℓ\ell and hℎh imply that any two consecutive pairs of sets (Xk,Yk)subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘(X_{k},Y_{k}), (Xk+1,Yk+1)subscript𝑋𝑘1subscript𝑌𝑘1(X_{k+1},Y_{k+1}) satisfy the following three conditions:

  1. ⋅⋅\cdot

    Xk⊆Xk+1subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑋𝑘1X_{k}\subseteq X_{k+1},

  2. ⋅⋅\cdot

    Yk⊆Yk+1subscript𝑌𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘1Y_{k}\subseteq Y_{k+1},

  3. ⋅⋅\cdot

    either {|Xk+1|=|Xk|+1|Yk+1|=|Yk|casessubscript𝑋𝑘1subscript𝑋𝑘1subscript𝑌𝑘1subscript𝑌𝑘\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}|X_{k+1}|=|X_{k}|+1\\[2.84526pt] |Y_{k+1}|=|Y_{k}|\end{array}\right.  or {|Xk+1|=|Xk||Yk+1|=|Yk|+1.casessubscript𝑋𝑘1subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘1subscript𝑌𝑘1\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}|X_{k+1}|=|X_{k}|\\[2.84526pt] |Y_{k+1}|=|Y_{k}|+1.\end{array}\right.

Using these conditions as an inspiration, we define the network DIOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S} whose nodes are pairs (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y) of subsets of S𝑆S with Y⊆X𝑌𝑋Y\subseteq X, with source node s:=(∅,∅)assign𝑠s:=(\varnothing,\varnothing) and sink node t:=(S,S)assign𝑡𝑆𝑆t:=(S,S) (the details are given below, including the definition of the arcs). Each s𝑠s–t𝑡t path in this network encodes an interval order on S𝑆S. Although several of these paths encode the same interval order, we obtain a projection from the flow polytope of DLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷LO𝑆D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S} to the interval order polytope of S𝑆S.

4.6 The case of semiorders

The case of semiorders is a bit more involved. Semiorders are particular interval orders, so they correspond to profiles of interval orders having an additional property. We would like to build a new network whose s𝑠s–t𝑡t paths exactly correspond to the profiles of semiorders. We obtain the nodes of the new network similarly as those of DLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷LO𝑆D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}, but we store more information at each node. The crucial property on which we rely is well known (see for instance Bogart & West, 1999): an interval order is a semiorder if and only if it admits a representation by intervals such that no interval contains another interval unless they share an endpoint. We now state this property formally.

Proposition 5.

A relation R𝑅R on the set S𝑆S is a semiorder if and only if there exist two mappings ℓ,h:S→ℝ:ℓℎ→𝑆ℝ\ell,h:\;S\to\mathbb{R} such that, for all i𝑖i, j𝑗j in S𝑆S:

ℓ​(i)≤h​(i);ℓ𝑖ℎ𝑖\displaystyle\ell(i)\leq h(i); (23)
i​R​j⇔h​(i)<ℓ​(j);iff𝑖𝑅𝑗ℎ𝑖ℓ𝑗\displaystyle i\,R\,j\;\iff\;h(i)<\ell(j); (24)
ℓ​(i)<ℓ​(j)⟹h​(i)≤h​(j).ℓ𝑖ℓ𝑗ℎ𝑖ℎ𝑗\displaystyle\ell(i)<\ell(j)\implies h(i)\leq h(j). (25)

Proposition 5 can be easily deduced from Proposition 4 (direct proofs also exist, see for instance Bogart & West 1999).

The network we build for semiorders has as nodes all triples (X,Y,L)𝑋𝑌𝐿(X,Y,L) with Y⊆X⊆S𝑌𝑋𝑆Y\subseteq X\subseteq S and with L𝐿L a linear order on X∖Y𝑋𝑌X\setminus Y. (Notice that when X∖Y=∅𝑋𝑌X\setminus Y=\varnothing, we must have L=∅𝐿L=\varnothing.) The source and sink nodes are s:=(∅,∅,∅)assign𝑠s:=(\varnothing,\varnothing,\varnothing) and t:=(S,S,∅)assign𝑡𝑆𝑆t:=(S,S,\varnothing), respectively. To motivate the later specification of arcs, we show how each representation of a specific type of a semiorder generates a sequence of nodes that eventually becomes an s𝑠s–t𝑡t path. Given a representation ℓℓ\ell, hℎh as in Proposition 5 for a semiorder R𝑅R, first adjust the values of ℓℓ\ell, hℎh to get a representation where ℓℓ\ell, hℎh are one-to-one and where ℓ​(S)∩h​(S)=∅ℓ𝑆ℎ𝑆\ell(S)\cap h(S)=\varnothing. Then, for any real number τ𝜏\tau with min⁡ℓ​(S)⩽τ⩽max⁡h​(S)+1ℓ𝑆𝜏ℎ𝑆1\min\ell(S)\leqslant\tau\leqslant\max h(S)+1, take the node obtained by setting X:=X​(τ)assign𝑋𝑋𝜏X:=X(\tau), Y:=Y​(τ)assign𝑌𝑌𝜏Y:=Y(\tau) as in Equations (21) and (22), and for i,j∈X∖Y𝑖𝑗𝑋𝑌i,j\in X\setminus Y letting i​L​j𝑖𝐿𝑗i\,L\,j exactly when ℓ​(i)<ℓ​(j)ℓ𝑖ℓ𝑗\ell(i)<\ell(j). An illustration is given in Figure 2. Varying the value of τ𝜏\tau, we thus generate a sequence of distinct nodes. We later specify the arcs so that each such sequence becomes an s𝑠s–t𝑡t path, and each s𝑠s–t𝑡t path is such a sequence. Furthermore, the resulting flow polytope provides an extended formulation of the semiorder polytope. The details are provided in Subsection 5.4. In particular, we show that the canonical description of this flow polytope grows faster in size than the extended formulations of our three other order polytopes. In the case of the semiorder polytope, we get an extended formulation of size 2Θ​(n​log⁡n)superscript2Θ𝑛𝑛2^{\Theta(n\log n)}, while for the other order polytopes, we obtain extended formulations of size 2Θ​(n)superscript2Θ𝑛2^{\Theta(n)}.

5 Customizing Extended Formulations as Network Flow Polytopes

In the next four subsections, we give detailed constructions and proofs of the results announced in Section 4.

5.1 The case of the linear order polytope

The network DLOS=(N,A)superscriptsubscript𝐷LO𝑆𝑁𝐴D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}=(N,A) we use for the case of linear orders of S𝑆S is defined by

N𝑁\displaystyle N :=assign\displaystyle:= {X​X⊆S},𝑋𝑋𝑆\displaystyle\{X{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}X\subseteq S\},
A𝐴\displaystyle A :=assign\displaystyle:= {(X,Z)∈N×N​X⊂Z,|Z|=|X|+1}formulae-sequence𝑋𝑍𝑁𝑁𝑋𝑍𝑍𝑋1\displaystyle\{(X,Z)\in N\times N{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}X\subset Z,\ |Z|=|X|+1\}

(in technical terms, the network DLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷LO𝑆D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S} is the “Hasse diagram” of the “Boolean lattice” of S𝑆S). Thus, |N|=2n𝑁superscript2𝑛|N|=2^{n} and |A|=n​ 2n−1𝐴𝑛superscript2𝑛1|A|=n\,2^{n-1}. The source and sink nodes are s:=∅assign𝑠s:=\varnothing and t:=Sassign𝑡𝑆t:=S, respectively. We now prove that the resulting flow polytope F​(DLOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷LO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}) projects in a natural way onto the linear order polytope PLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑆P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}.

Theorem 1.

Let π𝜋\pi be the projection from ℝAsuperscriptℝ𝐴\mathbb{R}^{A} to ℝS⋆Ssuperscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆\mathbb{R}^{S\star S}, mapping a point Φ∈ℝAΦsuperscriptℝ𝐴\Phi\in\mathbb{R}^{A} to the point x∈ℝS⋆S𝑥superscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆x\in\mathbb{R}^{S\star S} specified for all distinct i𝑖i, j𝑗j in S𝑆S by

x(i,j):=∑{Φa a=(X,Z)∈A,i∈X and j∈Z∖X}.x_{(i,j)}:=\sum\{\Phi_{a}{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}a=(X,Z)\in A,\ i\in X\textrm{ and }j\in Z\setminus X\}. (26)

The projection π𝜋\pi maps the flow polytope F​(DLOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷LO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}) onto the linear order polytope PLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑆P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}. As a consequence, the canonical description of the flow polytope F​(DLOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷LO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}), as in Equation (16), forms an extended formulation of PLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑆P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S} with description size n​ 2n−1𝑛superscript2𝑛1n\,2^{n-1}.

Proof.

It suffices to prove that the image of the vertex set of F​(DLOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷LO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}) under the projection π𝜋\pi is exactly the vertex set of PL​OSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝐿𝑂𝑆P_{LO}^{S}.

First, consider a vertex v𝑣v of PL​OSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝐿𝑂𝑆P_{LO}^{S}. Then v𝑣v is the characteristic vector of a linear order R𝑅R on S𝑆S. By considering any ordinal representation u:S→ℝ:𝑢→𝑆ℝu:~{}S\to\mathbb{R} of R𝑅R and the corresponding profile, we get an s𝑠s–t𝑡t path in DLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷LO𝑆D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}, say P𝑃P. The characteristic vector χA​(P)superscript𝜒𝐴𝑃\chi^{A(P)} of the set of arcs of this path is a vertex of F​(DLOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷LO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}). We establish that π​(χA​(P))=v𝜋superscript𝜒𝐴𝑃𝑣\pi(\chi^{A(P)})=v, i.e., Φ=χA​(P)Φsuperscript𝜒𝐴𝑃\Phi=\chi^{A(P)} in (26) yields x(i,j)=v(i,j)subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗subscript𝑣𝑖𝑗x_{(i,j)}=v_{(i,j)} for all distinct alternatives i𝑖i and j𝑗j of S𝑆S.

We evaluate the right-hand side of (26) at Φ:=χA​(P)assignΦsuperscript𝜒𝐴𝑃\Phi:=\chi^{A(P)}. The conditions i∈X𝑖𝑋i\in X and j∈Z∖X𝑗𝑍𝑋j\in Z\setminus X imply u​(i)<u​(j)𝑢𝑖𝑢𝑗u(i)<u(j), and so i​R​j𝑖𝑅𝑗i\,R\,j. Moreover, they also imply Z=X∪{j}𝑍𝑋𝑗Z=X\cup\{j\}, because here X⊂Z𝑋𝑍X\subset Z and |Z|=|X|+1𝑍𝑋1|Z|=|X|+1. By definition of the characteristic vector Φ=χA​(P)Φsuperscript𝜒𝐴𝑃\Phi=\chi^{A(P)}, the value ΦasubscriptΦ𝑎\Phi_{a} for any arc a𝑎a is 00 or 111. From what we just proved, Φa=1subscriptΦ𝑎1\Phi_{a}=1 can occur in (26) only for the unique arc (X,Z)𝑋𝑍(X,Z) such that Z={k∈S​ ​u​(k)≤u​(j)}𝑍𝑘𝑆 𝑢𝑘𝑢𝑗Z=\{k\in S{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}u(k)\leq u(j)\} and X=Z∖{j}𝑋𝑍𝑗X=Z\setminus\{j\}. Thus, we have x(i,j)=1subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗1x_{(i,j)}=1 in (26) if and only if i​R​j𝑖𝑅𝑗i\,R\,j (and x(i,j)=0subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗0x_{(i,j)}=0 otherwise). This establishes π​(χA​(P))=v𝜋superscript𝜒𝐴𝑃𝑣\pi(\chi^{A(P)})=v.

Second, consider a vertex ΦΦ\Phi of F​(DLOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷LO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}). Then ΦΦ\Phi is the characteristic vector of the set of arcs of an s𝑠s–t𝑡t path in DLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷LO𝑆D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}. This path produces a profile that in turn represents a unique linear order R𝑅R. Letting v𝑣v denote the characteristic vector of R𝑅R, we again have π​(Φ)=v𝜋Φ𝑣\pi(\Phi)=v.

The canonical description of the flow polytope F​(DLOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷LO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}) has n​ 2n−1𝑛superscript2𝑛1n\,2^{n-1} inequalities. ∎

Remark 1.

Recall that, for n=8𝑛8n=8, the linear order polytope has at least 488,602,996488602996488{,}602{,}996 facets. In contrast, the size of the canonical description of the corresponding flow polytope F𝐹F is only 1,02410241{,}024. Even for n=6𝑛6n=6 or n=7𝑛7n=7, the minimal description of PL​OSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝐿𝑂𝑆P_{LO}^{S} has size larger than the canonical description of the extended formulation.

5.2 The case of the weak order polytope

For the weak orders of S𝑆S, we define the network DWOS=(N,A)superscriptsubscript𝐷WO𝑆𝑁𝐴D_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}=(N,A) by

N𝑁\displaystyle N :=assign\displaystyle:= {X​X⊆S},𝑋𝑋𝑆\displaystyle\{X{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}X\subseteq S\},
A𝐴\displaystyle A :=assign\displaystyle:= {(X,Z)∈N×N​X⊂Z}𝑋𝑍𝑁𝑁𝑋𝑍\displaystyle\{(X,Z)\in N\times N{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}X\subset Z\}

with the source and sink nodes s:=∅assign𝑠s:=\varnothing and t:=Sassign𝑡𝑆t:=S, respectively (i.e., the “Boolean lattice” (𝒫​(S),⊂)𝒫𝑆(\mathcal{P}(S),\subset) of S𝑆S with strict inclusion). Clearly, we have |N|=2n𝑁superscript2𝑛|N|=2^{n}. Because each arc (X,Z)𝑋𝑍(X,Z) of DWOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷WO𝑆D_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S} can be encoded as a word of size n𝑛n on the alphabet {a,b,c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a,b,c\} having at least one b𝑏b (the letters a𝑎a, b𝑏b and c𝑐c correspond to alternatives of X𝑋X, Z∖X𝑍𝑋Z\setminus X and S∖Z𝑆𝑍S\setminus Z, respectively), we see that |A|=3n−2n𝐴superscript3𝑛superscript2𝑛|A|=3^{n}-2^{n}.

Theorem 2.

Let π𝜋\pi be the projection from ℝAsuperscriptℝ𝐴\mathbb{R}^{A} to ℝS⋆Ssuperscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆\mathbb{R}^{S\star S}, mapping a point ΦΦ\Phi from ℝAsuperscriptℝ𝐴\mathbb{R}^{A} to the point x𝑥x in ℝS⋆Ssuperscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆\mathbb{R}^{S\star S} given by Equation (26) above. Then π𝜋\pi maps the flow polytope F​(DWOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷WO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}) to the weak order polytope PWOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃WO𝑆P_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}. This yields the extended formulation F​(DWOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷WO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}) of PWOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃WO𝑆P_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}, whose canonical description has size 3n−2nsuperscript3𝑛superscript2𝑛3^{n}-2^{n}.

Proof.

The proof is parallel to that of Theorem 1, hence we provide only a sketch. Take any vertex v𝑣v of the weak order polytope PWOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃WO𝑆P_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}, with v𝑣v encoding the weak order R𝑅R. Then v𝑣v is the image by π𝜋\pi of a well defined vertex χA​(P)superscript𝜒𝐴𝑃\chi^{A(P)} of the flow polytope F​(DWOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷WO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}). To obtain χA​(P)superscript𝜒𝐴𝑃\chi^{A(P)}, take P𝑃P to be the path in (𝒫​(S),⊂)𝒫𝑆(\mathcal{P}(S),\subset) resulting from the weak order R𝑅R. Here, for a given weak order R𝑅R and distinct alternatives i𝑖i, j𝑗j in X𝑋X, the special pair (X,Z)𝑋𝑍(X,Z) in (26) consists of the smallest set Z𝑍Z in the profile of R𝑅R that contains j𝑗j, while X𝑋X is just the set preceding Z𝑍Z in the profile. ∎

Remark 2.

Recall that, for n=5𝑛5n=5, the weak order polytope PW​OSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑊𝑂𝑆P_{WO}^{S} has 75,8347583475{,}834 facets (Regenwetter & Davis-Stober, 2012). In constrast, the size of the canonical description of the corresponding flow polytope F​(DWOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷WO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}) is only 211211211.

5.3 The case of the interval order polytope

The network DIOS=(N,A)superscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆𝑁𝐴D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}=(N,A) for the interval order polytope of S𝑆S is defined as follows:

N𝑁\displaystyle N :=assign\displaystyle:= {(X,Y)​Y⊆X⊆S},𝑋𝑌𝑌𝑋𝑆\displaystyle\{(X,Y){\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}Y\subseteq X\subseteq S\},
A𝐴\displaystyle A :=assign\displaystyle:= {((X,Y),(Z,T))∈N×NX⊆Z,Y⊆T,andeither |Z|=|X|+1,|T|=|Y|or |Z|=|X|,|T|=|Y|+1}.\displaystyle\left\{((X,Y),(Z,T))\in N\times N\;\vrule height=23.0pt,width=1.0pt,depth=14.0pt\;\begin{array}[]{l}X\subseteq Z,\;Y\subseteq T,\;\text{and}\\ \begin{array}[]{rl}\text{either~{}}&|Z|=|X|+1,\;|T|=|Y|\\ \text{or~{}}&|Z|=|X|,\;|T|=|Y|+1\end{array}\end{array}\right\}.

We choose the source and sink nodes to be s:=(∅,∅)assign𝑠s:=(\varnothing,\varnothing) and t:=(S,S)assign𝑡𝑆𝑆t:=(S,S), respectively.

Lemma 1.

The numbers of nodes and arcs in the network DIOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S} are

|N|=3nand|A|=2​n​ 3n−1,formulae-sequence𝑁superscript3𝑛and𝐴2𝑛superscript3𝑛1|N|=3^{n}\quad\textrm{and}\quad|A|=2\,n\,3^{n-1}, (29)

respectively.

Proof.

Let S={s1,s2,…,sn}𝑆subscript𝑠1subscript𝑠2…subscript𝑠𝑛S=\{s_{1},s_{2},\ldots,s_{n}\}. Consider a word ω=ω1​ω2​⋯​ωn𝜔subscript𝜔1subscript𝜔2⋯subscript𝜔𝑛\omega=\omega_{1}\omega_{2}\cdots\omega_{n} of size n𝑛n on the alphabet {a,b,c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a,b,c\}. To each such word ω𝜔\omega, we associate a pair of sets (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y) such that Y⊆X⊆S𝑌𝑋𝑆Y\subseteq X\subseteq S by letting Y={si∈S​ ​ωi=a}𝑌subscript𝑠𝑖𝑆 subscript𝜔𝑖𝑎Y=\{s_{i}\in S{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}\omega_{i}=a\} and X={si∈S​ ​ωi∈{a,b}}𝑋subscript𝑠𝑖𝑆 subscript𝜔𝑖𝑎𝑏X=\{s_{i}\in S{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}\omega_{i}\in\{a,b\}\}. We obtain a bijection from the set of words of size n𝑛n on the alphabet {a,b,c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a,b,c\} to the node set of the network DIOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}. Thus, we have |N|=3n𝑁superscript3𝑛|N|=3^{n}.

Now, consider a word ω=ω1​ω2​⋯​ωn𝜔subscript𝜔1subscript𝜔2⋯subscript𝜔𝑛\omega=\omega_{1}\omega_{2}\cdots\omega_{n} of size n𝑛n on the alphabet {a,b,c\{a,b,c, d,e}d,e\} containing either exactly one d𝑑d and no e𝑒e, or exactly one e𝑒e and no d𝑑d. We associate an arc ((X,Y),(Z,T))𝑋𝑌𝑍𝑇((X,Y),(Z,T)) of the network DIOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S} to each such word, as follows. We let

X𝑋\displaystyle X :=assign\displaystyle:= {si∈S​ωi∈{a,b,e}},subscript𝑠𝑖𝑆subscript𝜔𝑖𝑎𝑏𝑒\displaystyle\{s_{i}\in S{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}\omega_{i}\in\{a,b,e\}\},
Y𝑌\displaystyle Y :=assign\displaystyle:= {si∈S​ωi=a},subscript𝑠𝑖𝑆subscript𝜔𝑖𝑎\displaystyle\{s_{i}\in S{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}\omega_{i}=a\},
Z𝑍\displaystyle Z :=assign\displaystyle:= {si∈S​ωi∈{a,b,d,e}},subscript𝑠𝑖𝑆subscript𝜔𝑖𝑎𝑏𝑑𝑒\displaystyle\{s_{i}\in S{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}\omega_{i}\in\{a,b,d,e\}\},
T𝑇\displaystyle T :=assign\displaystyle:= {si∈S​ωi∈{a,e}}.subscript𝑠𝑖𝑆subscript𝜔𝑖𝑎𝑒\displaystyle\{s_{i}\in S{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}\omega_{i}\in\{a,e\}\}.

This gives a one-to-one correspondence between the words of size n𝑛n on the alphabet {a,b,c,d,e}𝑎𝑏𝑐𝑑𝑒\{a,b,c,d,e\} containing exactly one of the two letters d𝑑d and e𝑒e, and the arcs of DIOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}. We conclude that |A|=2​n​ 3n−1𝐴2𝑛superscript3𝑛1|A|=2\,n\,3^{n-1}. ∎

The last result of this section is as follows.

Theorem 3.

Let π𝜋\pi be the projection from ℝAsuperscriptℝ𝐴\mathbb{R}^{A} to ℝS⋆Ssuperscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆\mathbb{R}^{S\star S}, mapping a point Φ∈ℝAΦsuperscriptℝ𝐴\Phi\in\mathbb{R}^{A} to the point x∈ℝS⋆S𝑥superscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆x\in\mathbb{R}^{S\star S} given, for all (i,j)∈S⋆S𝑖𝑗⋆𝑆𝑆(i,j)\in S\star S, by

x(i,j):=∑{Φa a=((X,Y),(Z,T))∈A,i∈Y,j∈Z∖X}.x_{(i,j)}:=\sum\{\Phi_{a}{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}a=((X,Y),(Z,T))\in A,\ i\in Y,\ j\in Z\setminus X\}. (30)

Then π𝜋\pi maps the flow polytope of DIOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S} onto the interval order polytope of S𝑆S. Thus, the canonical description of F​(DIOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}) is an extended formulation of PIOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃IO𝑆P_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S} with description size |A|=2​n​ 3n−1𝐴2𝑛superscript3𝑛1|A|=2\,n\,3^{n-1}.

Proof.

The structure of the proof is similar to that of Theorem 1 (see however Remark 3 below). We show that the image of the vertex set of F​(DIOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}) under the projection π𝜋\pi is exactly the vertex set of PI​OSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝐼𝑂𝑆P_{IO}^{S}.

Consider a vertex v=xR𝑣superscript𝑥𝑅v=x^{R} of PI​OSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝐼𝑂𝑆P_{IO}^{S} and a vertex Φ=χA​(P)Φsuperscript𝜒𝐴𝑃\Phi=\chi^{A(P)} of F​(DIOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}) such that ΦΦ\Phi encodes the profile of some ordinal representation of the interval order R𝑅R, say by injective mappings ℓℓ\ell and hℎh from S𝑆S to ℝℝ\mathbb{R} with ℓ​(S)∩h​(S)=∅ℓ𝑆ℎ𝑆\ell(S)\cap h(S)=\varnothing. It suffices to prove that π​(Φ)=v𝜋Φ𝑣\pi(\Phi)=v in this case (notice that each vertex of F​(DIOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}) comes from some profile of some interval order).

Let i𝑖i and j𝑗j be two distinct alternatives of S𝑆S. The right-hand side of (26) must give Z=X+{j}𝑍𝑋𝑗Z=X+\{j\} and Y=T𝑌𝑇Y=T (by the definition of the arcs in A𝐴A). In other words, given the profile, the arc a=((X,Y),(Z,T))𝑎𝑋𝑌𝑍𝑇a=((X,Y),(Z,T)) is completely determined by i𝑖i and j𝑗j. Moreover, such an arc can exist in A​(P)𝐴𝑃A(P) only if we have i​R​j𝑖𝑅𝑗i\,R\,j. Hence, the right-hand side of (26) equals 111 if and only if i​R​j𝑖𝑅𝑗i\,R\,j holds (and 00 otherwise), thus x(i,j)=v(i,j)subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗subscript𝑣𝑖𝑗x_{(i,j)}=v_{(i,j)}. ∎

Remark 3.

In the proofs of Theorem 1 and 2, the projection of the flow polytope on the order polytope induces a bijective mapping between the vertex sets of the two polytopes. This is not the case here: in general, several vertices of the flow polytope are mapped onto the same vertex of PI​OSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝐼𝑂𝑆P_{IO}^{S}. The reason is that different representations of the same interval order can lead to distinct profiles, and thus to different paths in the network.

Remark 4.

Recall that, for n=4𝑛4n=4, the interval order polytope has 191191191 facets. This is less than the size of the canonical description of the flow polytope F​(DIOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}) with |S|=4𝑆4|S|=4, which is 216216216. For larger values of n𝑛n, we do not know the exact number of facets of the interval order polytope. However, a lower bound on this number follows from Doignon & Rexhep (2016, Theorem 8 and Corollary 1): the interval order polytope F​(DIOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}) has at least as many facets as there are ‘PC-graphs’ on S𝑆S, where a PC-graph is a directed graph in which any node is the tail of at most one arc, and the head of at most one arc (in other words, a PC-graph is a node-disjoint union of paths and cycles plus maybe isolated nodes). For small numbers of alternatives, we provide in Table 1 both the resulting lower bound on the size of any linear description of the interval order polytope PI​Onsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝐼𝑂𝑛P_{IO}^{n}, and the exact size of the canonical description of the flow polytope F​(DIOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}). The flow polytope definitely has a smaller description size for n=6𝑛6n=6 (the same could hold for n=5𝑛5n=5). It is not difficult to see that the same assertion holds for n≥7𝑛7n\geq 7.

5.4 The case of the semiorder polytope

The network DSOS=(N,A)superscriptsubscript𝐷SO𝑆𝑁𝐴D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}=(N,A) we build for the semiorder polytope of S𝑆S is more structured than the one for the interval order polytope of S𝑆S. The nodes of DSOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷SO𝑆D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S} are of the form (X,Y,L)𝑋𝑌𝐿(X,Y,L) where X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y are subsets of S𝑆S such that Y⊆X𝑌𝑋Y\subseteq X, and L𝐿L is a linear order on X∖Y𝑋𝑌X\setminus Y (recall that when X∖Y=∅𝑋𝑌X\setminus Y=\varnothing we have L=∅𝐿L=\varnothing). Thus,

N𝑁\displaystyle N =\displaystyle= {(X,Y,L)​Y⊆X⊆S,L​ linear order on ​X∖Y}.formulae-sequence𝑋𝑌𝐿𝑌𝑋𝑆𝐿 linear order on 𝑋𝑌\displaystyle\{(X,Y,L){\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}Y\subseteq X\subseteq S,\;L\textrm{ linear order on }X\setminus Y\}.

We now indicate when the pair ((X,Y,L),(Z,T,M))𝑋𝑌𝐿𝑍𝑇𝑀((X,Y,L),(Z,T,M)) of nodes from DSOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷SO𝑆D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S} forms an arc. There are two cases that we illustrate in Figure 2 in terms of levels in representations: (α𝛼\alpha) the threshold moves from τ=ℓ​(5)𝜏ℓ5\tau=\ell(5) to τ=h​(3)𝜏ℎ3\tau=h(3); (β𝛽\beta) it moves from τ=h​(3)𝜏ℎ3\tau=h(3) to τ=h​(4)𝜏ℎ4\tau=h(4). Formally, the two cases are:

  1.   (α𝛼\alpha)

    for some alternative i𝑖i in S∖X𝑆𝑋S\setminus X:

    Z𝑍\displaystyle Z =\displaystyle= X∪{i},𝑋𝑖\displaystyle X\cup\{i\},
    T𝑇\displaystyle T =\displaystyle= Y,𝑌\displaystyle Y,
    M𝑀\displaystyle M =\displaystyle= L+i,𝐿𝑖\displaystyle L+i,

    where L+i𝐿𝑖L+i means that we append i𝑖i at the end of the linear order L𝐿L;

  2.   (β𝛽\beta)

    for the alternative j𝑗j in X∖Y𝑋𝑌X\setminus Y which is the first one in L𝐿L:

    Z𝑍\displaystyle Z =\displaystyle= X,𝑋\displaystyle X,
    T𝑇\displaystyle T =\displaystyle= Y∪{j},𝑌𝑗\displaystyle Y\cup\{j\},
    M𝑀\displaystyle M =\displaystyle= L−j,𝐿𝑗\displaystyle L-j,

    where L−j𝐿𝑗L-j means the linear order induced by L𝐿L on Z∖T=(X∖Y)∖{j}𝑍𝑇𝑋𝑌𝑗Z\setminus T=(X\setminus Y)\setminus\{j\}.

The sink and source nodes are again s:=(∅,∅)assign𝑠s:=(\varnothing,\varnothing) and t:=(S,S)assign𝑡𝑆𝑆t:=(S,S), respectively.

Lemma 2.

respectively, and they satisfy

Proof.

To obtain a node (X,Y,L)𝑋𝑌𝐿(X,Y,L) of DSOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷SO𝑆D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S} with t:=|X∖Y|assign𝑡𝑋𝑌t:=|X\setminus Y|, we select first an ordered list of t𝑡t elements from S𝑆S. Next we select some subset Y𝑌Y among the n−t𝑛𝑡n-t remaining elements, and finally we set X𝑋X equal to Y𝑌Y augmented by the listed elements.

To count the arcs, notice that the number of arcs leaving a node (X,Y,L)𝑋𝑌𝐿(X,Y,L) equals n−|Y|𝑛𝑌n-|Y|. Assume again t=|X∖Y|𝑡𝑋𝑌t=|X\setminus Y|, and let ℓ:=|Y|assignℓ𝑌\ell:=|Y|. Then

|A|=∑t=0n(n​(n−1)​…​(n−t+1)​∑ℓ=0n−t(n−tℓ)​(n−l)).𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑛𝑛𝑛1…𝑛𝑡1superscriptsubscriptℓ0𝑛𝑡binomial𝑛𝑡ℓ𝑛𝑙|A|=\sum_{t=0}^{n}\;\left(n\,(n-1)\,\dots(n-t+1)\,\sum_{\ell=0}^{n-t}\binom{n-t}{\ell}\,(n-l)\right). (34)

Now

∑ℓ=0n−t(n−tℓ)​(n−l)=n​ 2n−t−(n−t)​ 2n−t−1=2n−t−1​(n+t).superscriptsubscriptℓ0𝑛𝑡binomial𝑛𝑡ℓ𝑛𝑙𝑛superscript2𝑛𝑡𝑛𝑡superscript2𝑛𝑡1superscript2𝑛𝑡1𝑛𝑡\sum_{\ell=0}^{n-t}\binom{n-t}{\ell}\,(n-l)=n\,2^{n-t}-(n-t)\,2^{n-t-1}=2^{n-t-1}\,(n+t). (35)

The first bound holds because the last term in Equation (31) is n!𝑛n!. On the other hand, rewriting Equation (31) as

|N|=n!​∑t=0n2n−t(n−t)!,𝑁𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑛superscript2𝑛𝑡𝑛𝑡|N|\quad=\quad n!\;\sum_{t=0}^{n}\;\frac{2^{n-t}}{(n-t)!}, (36)

we get |N|≤n!​e2𝑁𝑛superscript𝑒2|N|\leq n!\,e^{2}. Because the number of arcs leaving any node is at most n𝑛n, the upper bound on |A|𝐴|A| follows from the one on |N|𝑁|N|. ∎

Theorem 4.

Let π𝜋\pi be the projection from ℝAsuperscriptℝ𝐴\mathbb{R}^{A} to ℝS⋆Ssuperscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆\mathbb{R}^{S\star S}, mapping a point Φ∈ℝAΦsuperscriptℝ𝐴\Phi\in\mathbb{R}^{A} to the point x∈ℝS⋆S𝑥superscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆x\in\mathbb{R}^{S\star S} given for all i𝑖i, j𝑗j in S𝑆S by

x(i,j):=∑{Φa a=((X,Y,L),(Z,T,M))∈A,i∈Y,j∈Z∖X}.x_{(i,j)}:=\sum\{\Phi_{a}{\;\vrule height=9.0pt,width=0.9pt,depth=2.5pt\;}a=((X,Y,L),(Z,T,M))\in A,\ i\in Y,\ j\in Z\setminus X\}. (37)

Then π𝜋\pi maps the flow polytope of DSOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷SO𝑆D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S} to the semiorder polytope of S𝑆S. Thus, the flow polytope F​(DSOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷SO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}) is an extended formulation of the semiorder polytope PSOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃SO𝑆P_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}, with size |A|≤e2​n​n!𝐴superscript𝑒2𝑛𝑛|A|\leq e^{2}\,n\,n!.

Proof.

Once again, we show that π𝜋\pi maps the set of vertices of the flow polytope F​(DSOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷SO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}) onto the set of vertices of the order polytope, here the semiorder polytope PSOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃SO𝑆P_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S} of S𝑆S. Each s𝑠s–t𝑡t path in DSOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷SO𝑆D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S} produces a representation of some interval order R𝑅R, exactly as in the proof of Theorem 3. Next, taking into account the ordering L𝐿L in any network node (X,Y,L)𝑋𝑌𝐿(X,Y,L), we see that the representation thus obtained has no interval strictly including another one. By Theorem 23, R𝑅R is then a semiorder. The rest of the proof is similar to the proof of Theorem 3. ∎

Remark 5.

Recall that, for n=4𝑛4n=4, the semiorder polytope has 563563563 facets. The description size of the flow polytope F​(DSOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷SO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}) with |S|=4𝑆4|S|=4 is 520520520, which is less than the number of facets of the semiorder polytope. It is difficult to prove that this holds for all values of n≥4𝑛4n\geq 4, because only a very limited number of facets of semiorder polytopes are known. However we can prove that there exists a natural number n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} such that, for all n>n0𝑛subscript𝑛0n>n_{0}, the description size of the flow polytope F​(DSOS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷SO𝑆F(D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}) will be smaller than the number of facets of the polytope PSOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃SO𝑆P_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}. This is due to the fact that there are more facet defining inequalities for PSOnsuperscriptsubscript𝑃SO𝑛P_{\mathrm{SO}}^{n} than PC-graphs on n𝑛n elements (Doignon & Rexhep, 2016, Section 9), and more PC-graphs than chain gangs, the latter being the disjoint unions of paths plus maybe isolated nodes. Indeed, the number of chain gangs on n𝑛n elements equals n!​∑j=0n−1(n−1j)/(j+1)!𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑛1binomial𝑛1𝑗𝑗1n!\,\sum_{j=0}^{n-1}\,\binom{n-1}{j}\,/\,(j+1)! (Sloane, 2016, Sequence A000262), and so it becomes eventually larger than e2​n​n!superscript𝑒2𝑛𝑛e^{2}\,n\,n! for some n=n0𝑛subscript𝑛0n=n_{0}, and remains so for all n𝑛n larger than n0subscript𝑛0n_{0}222Computations suggest this happens with n0=21subscript𝑛021n_{0}=21.. Even if its description size happens to be larger for values of n𝑛n less than n0subscript𝑛0n_{0}, our extended formulation has always the advantage that its canonical description is available in a very simple form.

6 Interface between Flow Polytopes and Statistics

In this section, we briefly consider how our network flow polytopes interface with contemporary statistical methods for evaluating random preference models. Typical choice data used in evaluating random preference models are comprised of decision maker responses to a series of repeated paired presentations of choice alternatives (see Regenwetter et al., 2011a). We consider the case when pairs of options are offered and the decision maker must choose one (two-alternatives forced choice) or must either choose one or indicate indifference (ternary paired comparisons). Let p(i,j)subscript𝑝𝑖𝑗p_{(i,j)} and C(i,j)subscript𝐶𝑖𝑗C_{(i,j)} denote the probability and the number of times that a decision maker chooses alternative j𝑗j when offered alternatives i𝑖i and j𝑗j. Let 𝒑:=(p(i,j))(i,j)∈S⋆Sassign𝒑subscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑗𝑖𝑗⋆𝑆𝑆\boldsymbol{p}:=\left(p_{(i,j)}\right)_{(i,j)\in S\star S} and let 𝑪:=(C(i,j))(i,j)∈S⋆Sassign𝑪subscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖𝑗𝑖𝑗⋆𝑆𝑆\boldsymbol{C}:=\left(C_{(i,j)}\right)_{(i,j)\in S\star S}. Let L​(𝒑|𝑪)𝐿conditional𝒑𝑪L(\boldsymbol{p}|\boldsymbol{C}) denote the likelihood of any given data 𝑪𝑪\boldsymbol{C} as a function of probabilities 𝒑𝒑\boldsymbol{p}, (for examples involving multinomial distributions see e.g., Davis-Stober, 2009, Myung et al., 2005, Regenwetter et al., 2011a). In general, in a random preference model, the maximum likelihood estimate does not have a closed form solution and therefore requires convex optimization. The maximum likelihood estimate (MLE) for a given random preference model PℳSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃ℳ𝑆P_{\mathcal{M}}^{S} that is one of PLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑆P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}, PWOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃WO𝑆P_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}, PSOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃SO𝑆P_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}, or PIOSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃IO𝑆P_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}, given choice data 𝑪𝑪\boldsymbol{C}, equals

𝒑^𝓜𝑪:=argmax𝒑∈PℳSL​(𝒑|𝑪).assignsuperscriptsubscript^𝒑𝓜𝑪subscriptargmax𝒑superscriptsubscript𝑃ℳ𝑆𝐿conditional𝒑𝑪\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{M}}}^{\boldsymbol{C}}:=\operatornamewithlimits{argmax}_{\boldsymbol{p}\in P_{\mathcal{M}}^{S}}L(\boldsymbol{p}|\boldsymbol{C}). (38)

In a network flow representation, the MLE for PℳSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃ℳ𝑆P_{\mathcal{M}}^{S} can be calculated via the following optimization program:

(MLE-CP)min𝒑∈ℝS⋆S,Φ∈ℝ|A|−ln⁡L​(𝒑|𝑪)s.t.Φ∈F​(DℳS)𝒑=π​(Φ),(MLE-CP)subscriptformulae-sequence𝒑superscriptℝ⋆𝑆𝑆Φsuperscriptℝ𝐴𝐿conditional𝒑𝑪missing-subexpressions.t.Φ𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷ℳ𝑆missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression𝒑𝜋Φ\begin{array}[]{rrl}\textrm{(MLE-CP)}&\min_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\mathbb{R}^{S\star S},\Phi\in\mathbb{R}^{|A|}}&-\ln L(\boldsymbol{p}|\boldsymbol{C})\\ &\textrm{s.t.}&\Phi\in F(D_{\mathcal{M}}^{S})\\ &&\boldsymbol{p}=\pi(\Phi),\end{array} (39)

where DℳSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷ℳ𝑆D_{\mathcal{M}}^{S} is one of DLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷LO𝑆D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}, DWOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷WO𝑆D_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}, DSOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷SO𝑆D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}, or DIOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}, accordingly. This is a convex optimization problem because we minimize the opposite of the log-likelihood function, assumed to be convex, over a convex feasible region. Indeed, the two vectors of variables 𝒑𝒑\boldsymbol{p} and 𝚽𝚽\boldsymbol{\Phi} are only constrained by linear equations and inequalities, coming both from the canonical description (16) of the flow polytope F​(DℳS)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷ℳ𝑆F(D_{\mathcal{M}}^{S}) and the expression that 𝒑𝒑\boldsymbol{p} is the projection of 𝚽𝚽\boldsymbol{\Phi} by π𝜋\pi (i.e. its image by an affine mapping).

The solution of this convex program yields the MLE as well as the maximized likelihood value. This convex program can be solved computationally by standard methods in convex optimization such as polynomial-time interior-point methods, see Nesterov & Nemirovskii (1994). Alternatively, the vector of variables 𝒑𝒑\boldsymbol{p} can be eliminated from the formulation using the projection equalities, leading to

(MLE-CP’)minΦ∈ℝ|A|−ln⁡L​(π​(Φ)|𝑪)s.t.Φ∈F​(DℳS).(MLE-CP’)subscriptΦsuperscriptℝ𝐴𝐿conditional𝜋Φ𝑪missing-subexpressions.t.Φ𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷ℳ𝑆\begin{array}[]{rrl}\textrm{(MLE-CP')}&\min_{\Phi\in\mathbb{R}^{|A|}}&-\ln L(\pi(\Phi)|\boldsymbol{C})\\ &\textrm{s.t.}&\Phi\in F(D_{\mathcal{M}}^{S}).\end{array} (40)

This is now a convex nonlinear network optimization problem, see e.g. Bertsekas (1998) (note that while the objective function remains convex, it is no longer separable).

The maximum likelihood estimate 𝒑^𝓜𝑪superscriptsubscript^𝒑𝓜𝑪\hat{\boldsymbol{p}}_{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{M}}}^{\boldsymbol{C}} is obtained by projecting the optimum flow Φ^^Φ\hat{\Phi} (which is not necessarily unique).

The Bayes factor is a standard method for assessing the relative empirical evidence for/against either of two competing models. It is defined as the ratio of their respective marginal likelihoods (Kass & Raftery, 1995). Following previous approaches in testing random preference models (Davis-Stober et al., 2015), we compare the model PℳSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃ℳ𝑆P_{\mathcal{M}}^{S} to an “encompassing” model that places no restrictions on choice probabilities. Assuming suitably chosen prior distributions, the Bayes factor can be re-written as the ratio of two proportions: the proportion of the encompassing prior in agreement with PℳSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃ℳ𝑆P_{\mathcal{M}}^{S} and the proportion of the encompassing posterior in agreement with PℳSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃ℳ𝑆P_{\mathcal{M}}^{S} (see Klugkist & Hoijtink, 2007). We estimate these proportions by repeatedly drawing from the prior and posterior distributions and counting the samples that satisfy PℳSsuperscriptsubscript𝑃ℳ𝑆P_{\mathcal{M}}^{S}. Checking whether or not a sampled value of 𝒑𝒑\boldsymbol{p} satisfies a given random preference model, using the extended formulation via a network flow, reduces to solving the following convex optimization program:

(Bayes-CP)min‖𝒑−𝒑s‖s.t.Φ∈F​(DℳS)𝒑=π​(Φ),(Bayes-CP)norm𝒑subscript𝒑𝑠missing-subexpressions.t.Φ𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐷ℳ𝑆missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression𝒑𝜋Φ\begin{array}[]{rrl}\textrm{(Bayes-CP)}&\min&\|\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{p}_{s}\|\\ &\textrm{s.t.}&\Phi\in F(D_{\mathcal{M}}^{S})\\ &&\boldsymbol{p}=\pi(\Phi),\end{array} (41)

where DℳSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷ℳ𝑆D_{\mathcal{M}}^{S} is one of DLOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷LO𝑆D_{\mathrm{LO}}^{S}, DWOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷WO𝑆D_{\mathrm{WO}}^{S}, DSOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷SO𝑆D_{\mathrm{SO}}^{S}, or DIOSsuperscriptsubscript𝐷IO𝑆D_{\mathrm{IO}}^{S}, which can be solved in the same ways as (MLE-CP). If the optimal value of 𝒑𝒑\boldsymbol{p} equals 𝒑ssubscript𝒑𝑠\boldsymbol{p}_{s} then the sampled point lies inside the model, otherwise it does not. See Davis-Stober et al. (2015) for additional details on using sampling methods to calculate Bayes factors under the weak order polytope.

7 Optimality

Here we discuss the asymptotic optimality of our extended formulations in terms of size. It will be convenient to use the notion of extension complexity of a polytope P𝑃P, defined as the minimum size of an extended formulation of P𝑃P. Notice that the extension complexity is affinely invariant, that is, two affinely equivalent polytopes P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q have the same extension complexity, and that it is monotone in the sense that the extension complexity of a polytope P𝑃P is at least that of any of its faces F𝐹F.

Maksimenko (2017) recently proved that the correlation polytope

PCORn:=conv{x​x⊺∣x∈{0,1}n}assignsuperscriptsubscript𝑃COR𝑛convconditional-set𝑥superscript𝑥⊺𝑥superscript01𝑛P_{\mathrm{COR}}^{n}:=\mathop{\mathrm{conv}}\{xx^{\intercal}\mid x\in\{0,1\}^{n}\} (42)

is affinely equivalent to a face of the linear ordering polytope PLO2​nsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO2𝑛P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{2n} (the linear ordering polytope for a set of 2​n2𝑛2n alternatives). This implies that the extension complexity of PLO2​nsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO2𝑛P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{2n} is at least that of PCORnsuperscriptsubscript𝑃COR𝑛P_{\mathrm{COR}}^{n}, which in turn was proved to be at least (3/2)nsuperscript32𝑛(3/2)^{n}, see Fiorini et al. (2015) and Kaibel & Weltge (2014). Therefore, the extension complexity of PLOnsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑛P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{n} is at least (3/2)⌊n/2⌋superscript32𝑛2(3/2)^{\lfloor n/2\rfloor}. Moreover, since PWOnsuperscriptsubscript𝑃WO𝑛P_{\mathrm{WO}}^{n}, PIOnsuperscriptsubscript𝑃IO𝑛P_{\mathrm{IO}}^{n} and PSOnsuperscriptsubscript𝑃SO𝑛P_{\mathrm{SO}}^{n} all have PLOnsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑛P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{n} as a face, we see that their extension complexities are at least that of PLOnsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑛P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{n}. Since the extended formulations constructed in this paper for PLOnsuperscriptsubscript𝑃LO𝑛P_{\mathrm{LO}}^{n}, PWOnsuperscriptsubscript𝑃WO𝑛P_{\mathrm{WO}}^{n} and PIOnsuperscriptsubscript𝑃IO𝑛P_{\mathrm{IO}}^{n} have size 2Θ​(n)superscript2Θ𝑛2^{\Theta(n)}, this implies that the three corresponding extension complexities are also 2Θ​(n)superscript2Θ𝑛2^{\Theta(n)}, i.e. that these extended formulations are asymptotically optimal.

For the semiorder polytope, we only know that the extension complexity of PSOnsuperscriptsubscript𝑃SO𝑛P_{\mathrm{SO}}^{n} is 2Ω​(n)superscript2Ω𝑛2^{\Omega(n)} and at the same time 2O​(n​log⁡n)superscript2𝑂𝑛𝑛2^{O(n\log n)}. We remark that it is possible that the semiorder polytope admits an extended formulation with size 2Θ​(n)superscript2Θ𝑛2^{\Theta(n)} but no such extended formulation based on flows. Indeed, flow-based extended formulations are known to have strong limitations, see Fiorini & Pashkovich (2015).

8 Conclusions and Discussion

In this paper, we leverage extended formulations and network flow polytopes to work with random preference models for linear orders, weak orders, semiorders, and interval orders. Our results break through previous barriers in the number of choice alternatives for which parsimonious linear descriptions are known. One fundamental reason is that we provide a complete, linear description of the extended formulation (a polytope which projects on the polytope of choice probabilities permitted by the model). A second reason is that in many cases the extended formulation description is of smaller size than that of the initial polytope. However, in the case of semiorders, the extended formulation relies more heavily on the numerical representations of the relations and consequently entails an excessively large description. One interesting open question is to find a more parsimonious extended formulation in the case of semiorders, or prove that none exists.

A natural application of the extended formulations we have described is to expand empirical studies of fundamental structures (e.g., weakly ordered preferences) for larger numbers of choice alternatives than previously possible (Regenwetter & Davis-Stober, 2012). We leave this for future work.
